data.text: yeah, you can use Thule Tour rack or similar, but why? And do you think it is good idea to put much weight on either carbon tubes or increase unsprung mass to that level? If you need 50+ liters of space, yes, you need to use rack(s). But if you need that muck space, you should get a steel bike which is designed to been used with rack(s). And honestly I do not think anyone needs so much space - I can hike with a ~18 L, 4 kg baseweight bag for 3 days unsupported. With gravel bags you can go up to 43 L (but comfortably 35L) - so it is a better option up to 1 week unsupported. Yes, if you are plan to go further without option to have food/water, you should get a bike with front/rear racks, but avarage MAMIL doens't want to cross the Namib desert. Of course these are not strict facts, and at the end everyone shoul find their best solution - but as I see across the hiking or the bikepacking community, every beginner is taking way too much stuff. With lighter pack/less stuff the ride is much more enjoyable which I think would ultimately be the edge of the whole trip.

data.text: It‚Äôs all swings and roundabouts and it mostly comes down to how much you need to carry and your personal preference. Racks and panniers are substantially heavier (when empty) than saddle bags, obviously there is the weight of the rack itself but also the panniers tend to have mounting systems and reinforcement that make them a lot heavier than a typical saddle bag. However they generally hold a lot more stuff and if you need to carry a lot then they are the best way forward. But that can also be a negative as if you have the space you tend to fill it with stuff you don‚Äôt necessarily need. Also depending on the mounting system panniers can bounce quite a bit over rough terrain. The biggest thing for me is the balance of the bike. A rear rack and panniers is ok if it is balanced with some luggage on the front of the bike, but for me carrying the vast majority of weight just on the back ruins the handling of the bike and can also make it more likely to do a wheelie up steep climbs. Generally for trips of a few days a saddle bag, frame bag and bar bag have enough space to hold everything you need, and prevent you from bringing lots of stuff you don‚Äôt need. Longer trips or heading into remote areas may require more stuff and it‚Äôs more likely that panniers and fork bags etc become necessary.

data.text: The more important points are the three other points‚Ä¶i.e. that seat packs DO out the weight high, can make gettin on and off awkward, and limit volume due to their triangular shape. The points against panniers are equally valid. Although I would add on the plus side that it‚Äôs far easier to transport pannier off the bike than it is to transport bikepacking bags off the bike. However, using panniers vs using a seat pack (or more likely a seat pack/frame bag combination) is application specific. If you don‚Äôt have to do hike-a-bike or if you are planning on riding on smooth roads, panniers are far superior to bikepacking bags in terms of ease of use and organization. If you are planning riding somewhere where hike-a-bike is a possibility or where the road is more rugged, bikepacking bags win out‚Ä¶even with their higher load and the impact that has on handling.

data.text: No. Not at all. A seat bag is behind the center of gravity of the bike (which is about the belly button of the rider). Without bags, the rider loads the rear wheel more than the front (about 60% rear bias). Putting load behind the CG loads the rear wheel more, just as using only rear panniers do. Traditional road tourists using 4 panniers will usually load the front with small dense equipment so that the load is balance with a 60% heavier load over the front wheel mounted in a low position. This counters the rider‚Äôs rearward bias nicely and improves handling.
